column4: In 9.10 I cannot access any network as non-root. Not in gnome ($ firefox) nor on tty ($ ping). As root it works in gnome (e.g. sudo firefox) and tty (sudo ping). In the gnome user admin program, I checked all boxes including networking permissions for the ubuntu user. Still they can't connect. Any clue? Is this possibly related to kernel .config option that prohibits non-root network usage ?
what error do you get when you try to ping for example?
let me check
I need to setup something before I can test. 1sec
ping www.google.com: unknwon host (with non-root)
this is happening with any network interface (I tried 3 different devices)
try: dig google.com
& dig google.com\net.c:142 socket() failed: Permission denied\same line again\dig: can't find either v4 or v6 networking.
& dig google.com\net.c:142 socket() failed: Permission denied\same line again\dig: can't find either v4 or v6 networking.
when did you start getting this error? did you install anything ?
since I installed ubuntu
it never worked. I really suspect it is kernel related for that and other reasons...
did you tweak anything ?
yes I have an entirely different kernel configuration vs ubuntu kernel config
I am using the arm rootfs of 10.04 generated using rootstock program

so I actually have millions of things that are different from stock x86 ubuntu - but. if you assume that people test the rootstock generated ARM rootfilesystem I doubt the problem is on ubuntu side. I rather think my kernel config is messed up
the thing is I can perform all other stuff just normal. it is just the network that can't be accessed by non root
you'd probably have more luck in #kernel
ok thank you very much.
good luck
no activity there. assuming it is not the kernel, any idea what to check ?
some user/group thing or so?
try #kernelnewbies
